(39)111 ) and was now before the Committee was intended to present a comparative statement, in so far as that was possible, between the Departments concerned in allowance and pension schemes. . It was very difficult to make a direct comparison because of differences in the basis of schemes, but in so far as comparison was possible the Personal Injuries (Civilians) Scheme prepared by the Ministry of Pensions was more similar to the Workmen's Compensation Scheme than tliie others. The structure of the Civilian Injuries Scheme had two main features in which it was dissimilar to the Workmen's Compensation, namely that it took into account married obligations, and secondly, it might be said to fall into two parts, Short-term compensation and long-term compensation. The short-term compensation was not substantially more favourable than the Workmen's Compensation Scheme; for example, a single man got less, but a married man with two children more. As far as long-term compensation was concerned, the Civilian Injuries scheme gave more favourable terms. This scheme was framed to deal with the Civil Defence Voluntary Forces, assuming a basic rate of £3 a week. It also took into account the ordinary private soldier's pension arrangementSr The Workmen's Compensation Scheme benefits were markedly less generous in the case of long-term compensation where there might be a reduction to 13% in the compensation payable, whereas the Civilian Injuries scheme had no provision for any such reductionQ The total cost of the scheme excluding cost of administration, including medical and legal costs was eight million pounds, and taking into consideration the other factors, set out in paragraph 5 of his memorandum (Paper No. H.P. Accidents in that industry represented about 50',': of the total, THE SECRETARY FOR MINES said there was a strong demand from miners for an increase in the present rates. He could not, however, argue that the industry could not bear this extra cost; it would, for example, not interfere with ex-port trade. THE CHAIRMAN said that it appeared to him that there were two sides to the problem. First, would this proposal be yet another factor in the rising spiral of prices; and secondly, what reactions would it have on the position of other Departments who had to meet demands for increased pensions and allowances? THE FINANCIAL SECRETARY TO THE TREASURY said that his views had been set out in Memorandum Paper N0.H.P.C.(39)109 which he had circulated. The essential point to him seemed to be that the conditions which led to the setting up of the Royal Commission were entirely different from those which were now prevailing. He fully sympathised with the Home Secretary in the position which he found himself, but he thought that the Government would have to recognise that marry social services which t h e y might wish to see developed (and in many cases he was in sympathy with such developments) must now be postponed in view of the strain placed upon our financial resources by the war, and also in view of the fact that every such increase adds to the rise in wages and costs. In his view the Government should take a firm line. It would not be fair to place the odium of refusing to agree on the employers. THE MINISTER OP LABOUR said that if the Government were successful in holding a policy of minimum increase in wages, a sympathetic view must be taken of the position of the lower paid workers. He was convinced that workers all over the country would watch what happened in the case of the Workmen1 s Compensation Act. THE MINISTER OP HEALTH said that at a recent meeting which the Chancellor of the Exchequer had held in regard to Old Age Pensions, employers had pointed out the increase to the burden on industry, and the Chancellor had given them to understand that it would be necessary to improve the position of old age pensioners. The question in the employers' mind was whether the increase in old age pensions would lead to an increase in health benefits. Now there was to be a question of further burden in connection with the Workmen's Compensation Act. The Chancellor was going to meet the National Joint Advisory Council on the 6th December to explain the position frankly to them. In his view all these matters should be considered together including the stabilisation of the price of food. THE HOME SECRETARY said that he would be most anxious to keep the door open for the Royal Commission c-jntinuing its enquiries. The two points which required decision were in his view, first, whether it was reasonable to retain 30/- as a maximum and secondly whether the tapering scale should be retained or modified. It tapered at present from 75% to 50% and the Minister of Labour had pointed out the arguments in favour of adopting 66 2/3% following the International Labour Recommendation of 19S5 which had been widely adopted. Some disucssion ensued and the LORD PRIVY SEAL suggested that the Committee might be prepared to adopt the suggestion in the Home Secretary's supplementary memorandum H.P,C.(39) 111, paragraph 2, that the announcement to be made in the House should at any rate not refer specifically to rates of benefits but refer more vaguely to "such provisional legislation as may be practicable under war conditions". It was suggested that the statement should include proposals for dealing with nystagmus problems and rehabilitation measures. It was pointed out that a decision about Old Age Pensions would probably be taken before it was possible to take a decision with regard to Workmen's Compensation. THE MINISTER OP HEALTH said that a statement in the House of Commons to the effect that the Government would endeavour to formulate some provisional legislation on the subject of rates of benefits in consultation with the T.U.C. and representatives of employers and other interests, would involve some increase in such benefits. He, therefore, thought that it was not possible to deal with one side of the question, (Workmen's Compensation), without considering other sides, such as Old Age Pensions, Health benefits and so forth. He did not think the Committee ought to put any recommendation to the War Cabinet without referring to this point and he suggested that the words "and would be considered in connection with other legislation of the same nature" should be added to the proposed announcement. THE SECRETARY OP STATE POR SCOTLAND agreed with this view. It was pointed out that a statement of this nature would imply that the Government were contemplating alterations in other schemes as well which^might lead to an embarrassing position. THE MINISTER OP LABOUR said that it was most important that the Government should not be put in a position in which they had to deal with these various subjects together as it was the strategy of the Labour Party to attempt to get them regarded as a whole, whereas in his view they should be dealt with separately and on their merits. It was also pointed out that the question of increasing benefits under the Unemployment Assistance Board had been under consideration by the Committee on Economic Policy. Further, the Chancellor of the Exchequer had been considering the question of increases to Old Age Pensions.
